text: [music playing]

AMANDA DAVIES: There's a lot
of people at the moment--

and not just in
tennis-- celebrating
you and your resurgence.
Where does it come from?

ROGER FEDERER: I think from
a good break last year.

Probably took absolutely the
right decision to pull the plug
on the season after Wimbledon.

I mean, I couldn't have
played, to be quite honest.

But then, to really
announce it early, to say,

I won't be playing anymore
for the rest of the season,
it was a tough one.

Because I missed the Olympics,
US Open, World Tour Finals,
you name it.
All my favorite tournaments.

AMANDA DAVIES: Did you realize
you were playing as well as you
were at the start of the year?

ROGER FEDERER: I think practice
went very well in December.

I was actually surprised
how well I practiced.

But then I thought,
well, it's not a match.

And many guys feel good in
practice, and in the match
they sort of just really fail.

So my coach actually
told me at the time,

he's like, if you do well, as
well as you're doing right now,

I honestly think something
is possible in Australia.

I'm like, yeah, but at one point
it's going to catch up with me.
I haven't played six months.
My shoulder is going to hurt.
My knee is going to go bad.

My foot is going to hurt because
I haven't played any matches.

And I got into this groove
at the Australian Open
and things were going perfectly.

And I was able to pull it
through until the very end.

And at the end, it
was a fairytale.

And I couldn't
believe it happened.

AMANDA DAVIES:
Was there any part

of you after that success, given
the fact that so many people
have said, that's it.

He's never going to win
a Grand Slam again--

was there any part
of you that thought,
I'm going to call it a day now?
Go out on this high.
ROGER FEDERER: Not really.

Because the goal
of last season--

after doing surgery in
February, exactly a year ago,

sort of thing, and
then, not playing

for the rest of the year
at the end of the year--

was for longevity, as a
player but also as a person.
I wanted to be healthy.
I wanted to feel good.

And that's why, even
after Australia, it
was such a fairytale.
And you're right.

You could have just
sort of walked away

and said, how much
better can it get?
Well, it did get better.
I won even while I was in Miami.

So I did it for
the right reasons.

And I really didn't
think of it, to be quite
honest, after I won Australia.

Most important is for me to
stay healthy, number one.

Number two, if I can
win more tournaments,

bigger tournaments, as I move
along, that would be wonderful.

If there is a chance for
world number one ranking,
that would be great.

But I need to have a
discussion with [inaudible].

AMANDA DAVIES: Would you
change your schedule--
[laugh]
I would love it.

It would be great if it
was just a discussion.
ROGER FEDERER: Right.
It's not that simple.

AMANDA DAVIES: But is there
a little bit of you that

would contemplate changing your
schedule and your priorities
to regain the number one status?
ROGER FEDERER: Not really.
I just don't think I can.
I would like to.
At 23 years old, absolutely.

You can start saying, OK, I'll
play the last 20 tournaments

of the season if it
helps me getting a better
chance for world number one.

But then, that's exactly
when I get injured.
That's exactly when I burn out.

And that's exactly when
it all is going to end.

So that's why I did take a
break now for six, seven weeks,

and just really
relaxed the body.

I feel like the mind
also needs a break.

The stress and pressure
that I have every single day
from playing is a lot.
So I won't change anything.
If it happens, great.

And I really think it's a
long, long shot, but who knows.

I really hope I could do
very well at Wimbledon
at the US open this year.

AMANDA DAVIES: Did
you ever consider
not doing Roland Garros?

ROGER FEDERER: I mean, I
think it's actually still
an option right now.
I don't think I will skip it.

But we'll have to
see in, let's say,
four or five weeks how I feel.

When I get on the clay,
how my mood is then.

If I feel like I'm not 100% in
it, that I'm really fired up,

and I believe that
something is possible,
then it's better to skip it.

But then I think maybe the
break is a long one again.

Then, it will be 10
weeks until the grass.
That could be a bit long.

But I will take probably
a definite decision
in five weeks.
